summary: The document discusses the Assassination Records Review Board's decision to partially postpone the release of certain records related to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), citing historical interest and privacy concerns. It highlights the redaction of Social Security numbers (SSN) for privacy protection and includes details on payroll authorization forms and memorandums concerning staff employment and termination within the U.S. House of Representatives, specifically mentioning Kenneth D. Klein, a staff member of the HSCA. The document also notes the official termination of the Select Committee on Assassinations on January 3, 1979, and mentions that payroll adjustments and terminations required approval by the Committee on House Administration.
key_findings: The document was partially postponed due to significant historical interest and privacy concerns.
Social Security numbers were redacted to protect personal privacy.
The document includes payroll records and authorization forms for Kenneth D. Klein, a staff member of the Select Committee on Assassinations.
The Select Committee on Assassinations officially terminated on January 3, 1979.
Payroll adjustments and terminations were subject to approval by the Committee on House Administration.
